title: NFL says Texas 'bathroom bill' could put prevent state from hosting future Super Bowls
text:
February 10, 2017 5:32pm   5:32pm EST American Football, News, English, NFL, Houston Texans, Dallas Cowboys The NFL spoke out on Texas's "Bathroom Bill" Friday, saying that discriminatory practices would “certainly be a factor” in awarding fut NRG Stadium (Getty Images) 
Updated at 5:32 p.m. ET 
Updated at 5:32 p.m. ET 
Five days after Houston hosted one of the greatest Super Bowls ever, the NFL delivered a message to the state of Texas. 
The "bathroom bill" currently under consideration could sink the state's chances of hosting another Super Bowl in the near future. 
MORE: Sports fans in North Carolina pay price for desperate HB2 supporters' discrimination 
Texas's controversial Senate Bill 6 would require transgender people to use bathrooms in public schools, universities and government buildings according to their "biological sex." 
In a statement Friday, NFL spokesperson Brian McCarthy said any such law that is "discriminatory or inconsistent with our values" would "certainly be a factor" in awarding future Super Bowls. 
"We want all fans to feel welcomed at our events and NFL policies prohibit discrimination based on age, gender, race, religion, sexual orientation, or any other improper standard," McCarthy said. 
While the host sites for the next four Super Bowls are already set (it will be held in Minneapolis in 2018, followed by Atlanta, Miami and Los Angeles), Houston and Dallas could be expected to bid for a future game. 
The Texas bill is similar in scale and tone to North Carolina's controversial House Bill 2 (HB2) law. The state has paid a high economic price since that law passed in March 2016, as the NBA withdrew the 2017 All-Star Game from Charlotte and the NCAA withdrew several championship events, including first- and second-round NCAA basketball tournament games, with more sanctions looming if the law isn't repealed. 
A spokesman for Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick told TexasTribune.org that the law would not apply to professional sports stadiums, which would be free to set their own policy for bathroom use. 
"Despite persistent misinformation in the media, under Senate Bill 6, all Texas teams will be able to set their own policies at the stadiums and arenas where they play and hold their events," Patrick spokesman Alejandro Garcia said. 
However, the legislation would apply to most college athletic facilities. Given the NCAA has already set a precedent by withdrawing events from North Carolina, Texas could expect the same treatment. Watch This
